Bleeding Wounds
1. Stop Bleeding • Apply direct pressure on the cut or wound with a clean cloth, tissue, or piece of gauze until bleeding stops. • If blood soaks through the material, don’t remove it. Put more cloth or gauze on top of it and continue to apply pressure. • If the wound is on the arm or leg, raise limb above the heart, if possible, to help slow bleeding. • Wash your hands again after giving first aid and before cleaning and dressing the wound. • Do not apply a tourniquet unless the bleeding is severe and not stopped with direct pressur
2. Clean Cut or Wound • Gently clean with soap and warm water. Try to rinse soap out of wound to prevent irritation. • Don’t use hydrogen peroxide or iodine, which can damage tissue.
3. Protect the Wound • Apply antibiotic cream to reduce risk of infection and cover with a sterile bandage. • Change the bandage daily to keep the wound clean and dry.
